webTitle: AAA credit rating fear: there’s no need to jump at shadows

fields.standfirst: Australia is unlikely to be downgraded, but even if it were, the government should not be a slave to credit rating agencies
fields.body:
Whenever a state or federal budget is released, a story about the government’s credit rating usually follows. This week was no exception, with the Australian Financial Review leading very strongly with the headline that the credit rating agency Standard & Poor’s was saying “Australia’s AAA credit rating at risk”. There are a couple things to ponder about this story. First, is our credit rating in danger, and second does it matter?

First, it’s pretty clear the AFR over-egged the pudding rather a touch. It quoted S&P analyst Craig Michaels saying: “We would be looking for a narrowing of budget deficits as evidence of ongoing commitment to running finances prudently.” That pretty much is a ratings agency cold reading – they say that about every budget.

The AFR concluded by quoting Michaels as noting the chances of Australia being downgraded stood at one in three “at most” and that “provided deficits remain relatively small and we see the government committed towards balance over the medium term and debt remains comfortably low, then there’s not immediate pressure on the rating”.

So you can see why they ran big on “credit rating at risk”...

In any event, after the story appeared, Michaels told numerous news outlets, from the ABC, to The Australian to Guardian Australia that “the rating is not at risk”, because a less than one in three chance of a downgrade is the standard measure for a stable outlook.

Fortunately few in the market paid too much attention to the story, and the yields – the interest rate for Australian government bonds – are actually lower now than they were on budget day. Thus investors don’t seem to view Australia as a greater risk since the budget was handed down.

As former finance journalist Jim Parker noted on Twitter, the value of credit default swaps (CDS) for Australian government bonds remains very low. Credit default swaps are in effect insurance against credit risk – the higher the CDS premium, the more likely people think a government will default.

Secondly, the RBA assistant governor (financial markets), Guy Debelle, noted in a speech on Tuesday (the same day the AFR ran with its splash), that in recent years there has been “an increase in foreign holdings of Australian Commonwealth government debt”.

Debelle noted that much of the increase appears to have come from “increased ‘official’ holdings of Australian assets by foreign reserve managers, including central banks”.

So it’s pretty clear we’re seen as a safe place to invest, in spite of our “budget emergency”.

The second part is whether or not losing our credit rating matters.

The worry is that a credit rating downgrade will cause the yield on the government’s bonds to rise – meaning that it will cost more for the government to pay back its debt. As a general rule the higher your bonds are rated the lower the yield.

But there are, however, a lot of other factors that determine the interest rate the government will have to pay on its debt. For example Australia’s cash rate set by the RBA (currently at 50-year lows of 4.5%) is a major factor, so too is Australia’s expected inflation, and also very importantly is the yield of US government bonds.

In the bond market everything is connected to everything else, and everything is firstly connected to the US.

Australian government bonds generally follow the lead of US Treasury bonds. And over the past decade the yields for Australian government 10-year bonds average about 1.3 percentage points higher than those in the US.

In the past 18 months, the yields of US bonds have risen due to improved expectations about the US economy and also a belief that the US Federal Reserve will increase its interest rates. And so, as a result, the yield on Australian government bonds has also risen in that time – from around 3% to 4% for 10-year bonds.

And little of that rise has anything to do with our budget, credit rating or other domestic factors – we just followed the US.

Now if S&P alone were to drop Australia’s credit rating to AA+ and the others (Moody’s and Fitch) didn’t, the impact would likely be minimal – after all it would still be a minority opinion.

But let’s say for the moment that a downgrade would have an impact. Joe Hockey argued on Tuesday that “it would have an impact on every household that borrows money, either through a mortgage or credit card”.

He noted that “the sovereign rating, the commonwealth government rating, flows through directly to the costs of borrowing by the banks and that flows directly through to every household and every business. It also flows through to the states.”

Now he is right that it would flow through and have an impact, though the question is how much?

Just as the Australian government’s bond yields are related to those in the US, state government and local corporate bonds and securities yields are referenced to the Australian government’s:

So yes, if the government’s bond yields rise because of a credit downgrade, then so will everyone else’s – state governments and corporations, including banks.

But interestingly, despite Western Australia and Queensland having their credit ratings downgraded (from AAA to AA+ for WA and from AA+ to AA for Queensland), the difference (or spread) between the interest rate those state governments pay for their debt has actually become closer to the interest rate the Australian government pays on its bonds. Logically a credit downgrade should have seen the difference between the interest rates widen because the state bonds are viewed as less secure compared to the Australian government’s.

But, as the RBA noted, for some states, the difference on interest is at the lowest levels since 2006-07.

And what about our credit card and mortgages rates?

Well the RBA does not need to raise the cash rate just because a credit agency changes its rating of Australia. And it will only affect banks if it affects the cost of their borrowing compared to the cost they charge us.

During the GFC, bank funding costs soared because the difference between the interest they received and the interest they had to pay increased.

Now nearly 60% of banks’ funding costs come from long-term local deposits. People deposit money in a bank, the bank uses that money to give people loans. One way to look at the cost of this for the banks is to look at the difference between the rates you get for your term deposit and the cash rate set by the RBA:

Your mortgage interest rates may go up in the future, but it will be due more to the RBA raising the cash rate than Australia’s credit rating being downgraded.

Indeed the RBA noted in 2012 that when Standard & Poor’s and Fitch downgraded the credit ratings of Australian major banks from AA to AA-, it had “no discernible effect on these banks’ borrowing costs”.

A credit downgrade is not something you want, but should S&P begin to start viewing Australia more negatively it will not be the end of the world as we know it. And at the very least we should wait until they actually do start viewing us more negatively instead of jumping at shadows.

The aim of a government budget should not just be to please credit agencies – especially if the impact of keeping or losing their approval is debatable. Credit agencies worry about debt and deficits; governments need to also worry about unemployment, education, health, defence, inequality.

Governments should not ignore credit agencies, but neither should they be slaves to them.
